Fit dismal times for our solemnities.
Put on my robes give me my pentacle,
cense well Barnardo: bring me some fire in an earthen vessel
Now must I labour like a collier's horse.
sp.stage: After Bernardo had censed he bringeth in coals, and Alexander fashioneth out his circle then taketh his rod.
sp.l: My precious best approved and trusty servant,
Hence in all haste betake thee to thy beads,
Whilst these dark works of horror are in hand,
Red sandal is my fumigation.
sp.stage:
Standing without the circle he waveth his rod to the East.
And calleth upon Vionatraba.
To the West. Suseratos.
To the North. Aquiel.
To the South. Machasael.Conistro, et confirmo super vos in nomine eye, eye, ay; haste up and ascend pernomeu ya, ya, ya; he, he, he; va; high, high; ha, ha, ha; va, va, va; an, an, an;
Fiery exhalations lightning thunder ascend a King, with a red face crowned imperial riding upon a lion, or dragon: Alexander putteth on more perfume and saith.
sp.l: I conjure thee by these aforesaid names,
That thou receive no phantasmatic illusions.

sp.speaker: Devil
sp.l: What would great Alexander have with us,
That from our fiery region millions of leagues,
Beneath the sulphurous bottom of abyss,
Where Mammon tells his ever tried gold,
Thou callest me from strong business of high state,
From sure subversions and mutations
Of mighty monarchs, emperors, and Kings,
From plotting bloody fields and massacres,
Triumphant treasons and assassinates.
What's thy demand?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: I charge thee by the four recited names,
And by the dreadful title of great .
By which all creatures are sure sealed up,
By which the prince of darkness and all powers,
In earth and hell do tremble and fall down,
Show me the shape of that condemned man,
Which murdered my son the Duke of Candy.

sp.speaker: Devil
sp.l: Keep a firm station stir not for thy life,
Expect a messenger of trust stand fast,

div.stage: The devil descendeth with thunder and lightning and after more exhalations ascends another all in armour.

sp.speaker: Devil
sp.l: Sent from the foggy lake of fearful Styx.
Am I commanded by that puissant monarch,
Which rides triumphing in a chariot,
On misty black clouds mixed with quenchless fire,
Through uncouth corners in dark paths of death,
To do what thou demandest.

sp.speaker: Allex.
sp.l: Then by the dreadful names of Amioram,
Titepand Sadai show me that damned child of reprobation.
Which this night murdered the Duke of Candy.

sp.speaker: Devil
sp.p: Keep a firm station stir not for thy life,

div.stage: He goeth to one door of the stage, from whence he bringeth the ghost of Candy ghastly haunted by Caesar pursuing and stabbing it, these vanish in at another door.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Hold, hold, hold, hold; per todos santos now no more,
Caesar hath killed a brother and a father.

sp.speaker: Devil
sp.p: What wouldst thou more shall I descend?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Show me the person by whose impious hand,
Gismond Viselli, was done to death?

sp.speaker: Devil
sp.p: Keep a firm station stir not for thy life.

div.stage: He bringeth from the same door Gismond Viselli, his wounds gaping and after him Lucrece undressed, holding a dagger fixed in his bleeding bosom: they vanish.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Out, out, no more no more, my soul dissolves.

sp.speaker: Devil
sp.p: Say, say what wouldst thou more? descend,

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Beldachiensis, berolanensis, Helioren, descend, descend, iubeo, mando ▪ impero. Devil descendeth with thunder. Etc.

div.stage: Enter Bernardo.
Alexander tinketh his bell,

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Out out alas Bernardo I am wounded,
With grisly wounds and deep incurable.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Comfort yourself in God's name blessed father.
So long as no wounds of the body bleed.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: The cureless wounds I mean are of my body
Wounds both of my soul and body: but Bernardo
This is my comfort in calamity
Some shall pack after them for company
What's o'clock ?

sp.speaker: Barn.
sp.p: Very near six by saint Peter's bell

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Hast thee, then pass thee to my pothecary, bid him provide those drugs I spoke for yesterday, and bear them in all haste to Dominico Giglio take you those letters with you which are here, bid him deliver them Lodowick Sforza's name her lustful paramour; make haste and see that he dispatch it quickly, deliver him a purse from me for a token crammed with two hundred ducats, bid him be secret as he loves his life, hast and begone.
sp.l: Astor shall follow, I must have his lands
This thorn must be cut of being but tender
Then cut it soon whilst it is young and slender,
Lest growing great it prick thee to the bone
My lust importunes it and he shall die,
Sons, nephews, daughters, concubines, shall die.
My conscience is turned mercies enemy,
He that would rise to riches and renown
Must not regard though he pull millions down.

div.stage: Exit Alexander into the study.

div.head: Scen. 2.
div.stage: Enter Caesar Borgia with Caraffa and Bentivoli.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: Where is his holiness? where is my father?
Alas your son is slain; your hapless son,
My noble brother out alas, alas
Is murdered: in tender passion
Let curious search and inquisition
Be made through Rome to find the murderers:
I fear that traitorous Judas Cardinal
Ascanio Sforza with his complices:
I will not hold fraternity with him:
And 〈◊〉 behold my meaning blessed father:
〈◊〉 gain these robes, take here this hat,
and in these arms which I have buckled on
I do forswear all offices of church,
Until I be revenged for his death.

div.stage: He disrobeth himself and appeareth in armour.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: A foul red vengeance over hangs his head
Whose heart indurate or whose devilish brain,
Could execute conceive or meditate
So foul a murder of an innocent.
Caraffa with Bentivoli give leave
Somewhat I would in private have with Caesar.
Caesar dissemble not for that were vainExeunt Car. et Ben.
Whence comest thou.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.p: Directly from my chamber.

sp.speaker: Ale.
sp.p: Where didst thou here this news.

sp.speaker: C●s.
sp.p: Fishers which found his body brought the news.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Then he was drowned Caesar was he not?

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.p: It seems he was.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: What by some fisher.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.p: How should I know that.

sp.speaker: Ale.
sp.l: Sure by some subtle fisher that laid nets
For Candy's life and honour: but say truly,
Was it thy brother.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.p: Are not you my father?

sp.speaker: Ale.
sp.l: Ah that I never had been any father,
But speak again, man speak the truth and fear not:
Who slew thy brother Candy this last night,
Who trained him forth who walked along with him.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.p: Am I the keeper of my brother's person.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Execrable Cain; perfidious homicide,
Apparent villain what canst thou design?
Which I would know that thou canst hide from me.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: A plague upon your devils you deal with them,
That watch more narrowly to catch your soul
Than he which sought my brother Candy's death,
You know that Sathan is the lord of lies
A false accuser and dissembler,
Tell your false liars they be lying devils.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Caesar no more, Caesar no more, thou knowest.

sp.speaker: C●s.
sp.p: What know I?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: That I know, dissemble not.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: Suppose you know, suppose in wrath and fury
I killed my brother; can we mend it now?
He was not fashioned for these busy times:
He rests in peace, our peace rests in our swords.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Caesar thou dost unkindly vex my soul,
With rubbing up my secret miseries:
Incurred by seeking to lift up thy head.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: Pull me not down good father with your conscience:
Your conscience, father of my conscience is.
My conscience is as like your conscience,
As it were printed with the selfsame stamp.
I know my sins are burdenous, and bear them,
Your sins more heinous, yet your robes conceal them.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Out wicked and nefarious homicide.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: Upbraid me not, for if that lamp burn dim,
Which should give light to men in darkest night;
How can they choose but must in shadows err,
That follow the blind-glimmering thereof:
Doth this one petty fault appear so grievous?
Which if you well consider is no fault;
He was an honest man, and fit for heaven:
Whilst he lived here he breathed in misery;
And would have been enlarged: I set him free,
Now if I may compare your state with his,
Or your condition with my quality,
Have you not sold yourself unto the devil,
To be promoted to the papacy:
Have you not sold the livings of the church?
Are not your coffers crammed with beastly bribes,
With foul extortion, and base usury?
Have ye not (Since your inauguration)
Poisoned and done to death six Cardinals;
In devilish avarice to get their goods?
Have you not (Which is most abominable)
Committed incest with your only daughter;
And made me sin with her for company,
that both might reign in hell for company?
Did you not take of Georgio Bucciardo
One hundred thousand ducats from the Turk,
To kill his brother Gemen ottoman?
Have you not kept the pearl of Italy,
Astor Manfredi that young virtuous prince,
In beastly lust, and filthy sodomy.
Blasting the blossom of his towards youth?
Have you not now given order for the death
Of my dear sister, whom your passions caused
To kill her latter husband Di Viselli,
And robbed the noble Earl of his new spouse,
Only to cloak your vile impiety,

sp.speaker: Ale.
sp.p: Caesar the devil hath been thy schoolmaster.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: I pass your secret counsel with the devil,
Your avarice, ambition, perfidy,
Your bloody plots, inhumane cruelty,
Why then upbraid ye me with Candy's death?
A bastard of our house, degenerate,
In whom no spark or spiracle of honour,
Appeared to raise the race of Borgia.
But had I been lieutenant of your forces,
This arm had conquered all Romania,
France before this had trembled, Spain had stooped,
The Roman emperor had fawned upon us.
King Charles had been restrained, Frederick expulsed,
And Naples had been made our heritage.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: A triple joy succeeds a single grief,
I have engaged all to make Caesar great,
Caesar it suiteth with thy grace and glory,
To cloak my vices, I will pardon thine,
Let one of us excuse another's crimes,
And for this bloody fact so lately done.
As thou didst cunningly begin proceed,
To lay the guilt or imputation
On them whose death may do thee benefit:
And never was my soul better contented,
Then that our woes are with rich hopes prevented.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: Now stands Romania subject to my sword.
Imola furli, Camerine, and Urbine
Shall have the first charge, if I there succeed,
Have forward farther with a better speed,
Caesar oh nullo written in my guidon,
When with my troops victoriously I ride on.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Holla Bernardo, call in Caraffa with Bentivoly:Enter barn:
Ay now now now, my precious boy, my Caesar,
Prosecute as thou hast begun,
With art, look sullen and demure,
Hold down thy head, like one swollen up with sorrow,
They come, they come, say that those arms were put on,
In revenge of Candy's death.
The sovereign medicine of things past cure,
Is for to bear with patience and forget,
Caesar hath vowed revenge for Candy's death,
And in regard of Caesar's piety,
I make him general in his brother's place.

sp.speaker: Coes.
sp.l: And never shall I sheathe this sword in peace
Till it have wrought upon the murderer.

sp.speaker: Caraf.
sp.l: Happy success accompany my lord,
And in your battles give you victory.

sp.speaker: Bent.
sp.p: Is order taken for his funerals.

sp.speaker: Coes.
sp.l: Bentivoli take you no thought for that,
That is the greatest care, which troubles me.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Come on my lords, we will advise within,
For I must have your counsels in my grief. Exeunt omnes.

div.head: Scen. 3.
div.stage: Enter Lucretia richly attired with a viol in her hand.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Kind Lodowick hadst thou presented me,
With Persian clothes of gold or Tinsilry,
With rich Arabian odours, precious stones,
Or what brave women hold in highest price,
Could not have been so gracious as this tincture,
Which I more value than my richest jewels,
o Motticilla. Enter Motticilla.
Bring me some mixtures and my dressing boxes,
This night I purpose privately to sup
With my lord Cardinal of Capua.
sp.stage: Enter two pages with a table, two looking glasses, a box with combes and instruments, a rich bowl.
sp.l: Bring me some blanching water in this bowl. Exit motti.
Here I perceive a little riveling
Above my forehead but I wimple it
Either with jewels or a lock of hair,
And yet it is as white as the pure snow:
Oh God when that sweet marquess Mantova,
Did in Ferrara feast my lord and me,
What rich comparisons and similes,
He with ingenious fantasy devised,
Doting upon the whiteness of my brows?
As that betwixt them stood the chair of state,
Composed of ivory for the Paphian Queen:
Sitting in comfort after amorous conquest.
And kissed my forehead twenty thousand times.
Oft have I wished the colour of this hair
More bright, and not of such a Spanish dye,
And yet the Duke of Bourbon on his knees,
As the divinest favour of this world,
Did beg one lock to make a bracelet,
For which few hairs he garnished my head
With jewels worth six thousand crowns at least.
My beaming eyes yet full of majesty,
Dart love, and give bright luster to the glass,
As when the sun beams touch a diamond.
The prince of Salerne solemnly did swear,
These eyes were quivers which such shafts did bear
That were so sharp, and had such fiery touch,
As Cupid's arrows never had so much,
The rosy garden of these amorous cheeks,
My nose the gracious fort of conquering love,
Breathing attractive odours to those lovers
that languish and are vanquished with desire,
Gonzaga calleth it the silver perch,
Where Venus' turtles mutual pleasure search.
Sweet mouth the ruby port to paradise
Of my world's pleasure from whence issue forth,
Many false brags, bold sallies, sweet supplies,
A chin the matchless fabric of fair nature,
A neck two breasts upon whose cherry nipples.
So many sweet solutions Cupid sucked,
Give me some blanching water in this bowl,
Wash my face Motticilla with this cloth,
So 'tis well now will I try these colours.
Give me that oil of talc,
Take sarsenet Motticilla smooth my forehead.
sp.stage: She looketh in two glasses and beholdeth her body.
sp.l: I must delay this colour is it carnation right.

sp.speaker: Mot.
sp.p: O the true tincture of a damask rose,

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: What is it excellent.

sp.speaker: Mot.
sp.l: Most full of life.
And madam that's a precious lineament,
As ever I beheld to smooth the brows.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I will correct these arches with this mullet,
Pluck not too hard, believe me Motticilla,
You pluck too hard.
I feel a foul stink in my nostrils,
Some stink is vehement and hurts my brain,
My cheeks both burn and sting give me my glass.
Out out for shame I see the blood itself,
Dispersed and inflamed, give me some water.
sp.stage: Motticilla rubbeth her cheeks with a cloth.
sp.l: My brains intoxicate my face is scalded.
Hence with the glass: cool cool my face, rank poison,
Is ministered to bring me to my death,
I feel the venom boiling in my veins.

sp.speaker: M●t.
sp.l: Ah me dear lady; what strange leprosy?
The more I wash the more spreads on your face.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Send to my father; call physicians in,Exit Mo●●i
O Candy where art thou my comforter,
Dead and entombed; Lucrece must follow thee,
I burn I burn, o where is my dear lord.
My brains are seared up with some fatal fire.

div.stage: Enter a servant and physician with Morticila.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Dear lady cheer yourself, be not dismayed,
His holiness in haste hath sent relief:
His own physician to recomfort you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: For our dear lady's passion bring some water to cool my thirst.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Madam you may not drink,
Till you receive this one preservative.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: A foul unsavoury loathsome stink chokes up
My vital senses and a boiling heat
Sups up the lively spirit in my lungs.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: This poison spreads and is incurable,
Madam receive one precious antidote.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: What have I caught you Sforza,
Who painted my fair face with these foul spots,
You see them in my soul deformed blots,
Deliver me from that murthered man,
He comes to stab my soul I wounded him,
O Gismond Gismond hide those bleeding wounds,
My soul bleeds drops of sorrow for thy sake;
Look not so wrathful I am penitent.
Love and remorse did harbour in thine heart,
What dost thou beckon to me I will come,
And follow thee through millions of woes.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Sweet lady will you take a little rest,
It will refresh your spirits instantly.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: No rest until I see my lord again.

sp.speaker: Mot.
sp.p: Dear lady do you love your life, take rest,

div.stage: She taketh hold of Motti●ila.

sp.speaker: Luc
sp.l: From the pure burning coals of true contrition.
Methinks I see the lively counterfeit,
Of caitiff Cressid in her misery,
Engendered out of her disloyalty,
ah Moticilla whom I trained up
In cunning sleights and snares of filthiness,
Forgive me for that sin; live and repent.

sp.speaker: Mot:
sp.l: O God forgive me for my sins are great,
And if his goodness lend my life some space,
I will with penance call on him for grace,
And spend the remnant of my life in prayer.

sp.speaker: Luc:
sp.l: I can no more, death summoneth my soul,
Open thy bosom father Abraham,
Merciful father let thy mercy pass
Extend thy mercy where no mercy was.
Merciful father for thy son's dear merit
Pardon my sinful soul receive my spirit. Expirat Lucrece.

sp.speaker: Phi:
sp.l: Now is her soul at rest 'tis very strange,
As well the cause as manner of her death,
I have been studied in Hipocrates,
In books of Galen and old Avecine,
Observed the cures of divers learned doctors,
In France in Spain and higher Germany,
Yet never met with such an accent,
Bear in her body I will in all haste,
Bring woeful news unto saint Peeters palace,
His holiness will grievously lament. Exeunt omnes.

div.head: Scae. 4.
div.stage: Enter Caesar and Barbarossa soldiers drums and trumpets.

sp.speaker: Caes:
sp.l: Fellows in arms after our victories,
Had in the first front of our happy war,
With men of hardy resolution,
Now must we bend our forces against Furly,
Where that proud Amazonian Katharine,
Dareth defiance in the face of war,
And yet our hopes are sure, all passage clear,
And she before I lodge this restless head,
Shall bear the bondage of this victory.

sp.speaker: Bar:
sp.l: These proud presuming spirits of vain women,
Whose bloodless wounds are only bloody words,
〈◊〉 without reason, fight without resistance,
but on the face of grim devouring war,
With frowning forehead menacing his force,
They fall down on their backs as Venus did,
When Mars beheld her with a soldier's face,

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: Nay we must fight: I know the puissant spirit
Of warlike Kate the pride of Italy,
Sforza's brave sister and old Riario's widow,
Excellent valour, and deep policy
Must win it, if we purchase at her hands.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: And yet we be beforehand with the lady,
Having surprised her treasure and her sons,
As they were making their escape for Florence:
What shall we try renowned general?
And search her resolution.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: Shall we? doubt you not,
Nay though the walls of Furly were of steel,
These pledges should make passage for our powers,
And what? shall we stoop for those twenty ensigns,
Which this last night have entered their ports,
Nay were they ten to one within those walls,
Caesar (That carries fortune in his standard)
Would make them give ground and subject themselves.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Speak then at once renowned general,
Shall we go soldierlike to work at first?
Shall we salute her with our cannon?

sp.speaker: C●s.
sp.l: What? no Barbarossa not without a parley,
Fore-god I love her, and admire her valour,
And till we find her words prove empty squibs,
We give her all the noble rights of war,
Summon a parley. Sound drum, answer trumpet.
sp.stage: Enter upon the walls countess Katherine, Julio Sforza, ensign ▪ soldiers, drums, trumpets.
sp.l: What have we Pallas come upon these walls,
To bring confusion of our companies:
Doth proud Penthesilea live again,
Which sometime raging in the fields of blood,
Made passage with her angry sword through millions.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.l: I tell thee Caesar son of Alexander
A book befits thee better than a blade:
Percase in scorn thou wilt reply the like,
A distaff fits me better than a pike.
Know Caesar had I now so many lives
As here are stones or hairs upon your beards,
I would forgo them all before this honour,
Which my dear lord Riario did leave me,
The pledge of my dear love his children's patrimony.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: Speak in a milder key renowned Kate.
I love you well and all brave Sforza's race
Yet you must yield there is no remedy,
It is the churches right and I must have it.

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.l: Methinks a pulpit were more fit for thee,
But didst thou ever read saint Gregory:
That he which hunteth for authority,
Himself should govern direct and know well;
He did a deed of danger that advanced thee,
For proud ambition violates all right.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: Be not so bitter Kate a friend entreats you,
But if entreaties will not, look upon me:
Here standeth Cesar, the sharp scourge of Furly
And were your fort fenced with as many men,
As it is girt with stones Caesar would have it.
Subdue them and make pillage of their goods
And in resistance seal it with their bloods.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.l: What are your weapons sheathed in your throats?
Is every word a sword then shake hands Caesar:
Venture no further and we will be friends
But if your words have accents in keen swords,
And end in blood, than Caesar look on me:
I with defiance turn swords in your throats,
You shall not thrust that imputation
Upon our fex, for I will fight it out
So long as I can stand upon these walls.

sp.speaker: C●s.
sp.l: You would repent it, if you knew the worst,
Consider Kate be well advised first.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.l: Caesar at one word to discharge my conscience,
were there a cannon there to be discharged
Upon this fruitful womb the nurse of children,
And I sure piece mell to be torn withal,
If I would not surrender up this fort
Your cannon shot should plow these bowels up,
That vow to God and my dear husband made:
I never will infringe with perfidy:
I know thee bloody Caesar: the dishonour,
In yielding up thy reverend purple robes
Which should protect widows and orphans rights,
Appeareth well in taking unjust arms,
To wrong the widows and the fatherless
Either fight Caesar or forsake the field,
Persuade thyself alive I will not yield.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: Then I will show you what wars destiny,
Prognosticates, bring forth her ransom hither
sp.stage: Barbarossa bringeth from Caesar's tent her two boys.
sp.l: If nature be not quite extinguished
These pledges shall enfranchize you from war
I brought them to this purpose; that in them,
You with your friends might live in liberty.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.l: Never but with advantages dear lord.
Monster of misery what think'st thou Cesar
That I will yield mine honour for their safety?
Be not deceived thou hast surprised my children,
Riario's riches left in my tuition
And born out of these bowels; but dear boys,
Courage yourselves I will defend your honours:
I tell thee Cesar these my boys are taught
To bear with patience fates inevitable
These carry Sforza's spirit and their fathers;
I dare gage life and ask them they will choose,
To lack their lives before they lose their honours.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: Caesar in this hath offered like himself,
He proffereth to preserve your town untouched:
Your goods, your wives, your lives, your liberties:
But mark what fruits thy bitterness brings forth,
to make thine hard heart infamous for ever,
Before thy face these boys shall lose their lives
If thou surrender not without more parley.

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.l: Bloody 〈◊〉 I defy thy malice,
I spit defiance in thy coward's face.
Traitor to God and man hadst thou been Caesar,
Insisting on high terms of worth and honour
Thou wouldst consider that their blood is noble,
Thou wouldst consider that they be but children,
Thou wouldst consider that thou art a warrior
And that such noble blood spilt with dishonour
And trammed in with insidious treachery,
By God nor man in heaven nor earth below
Can be forgotten or abolished.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.l: Brave general you parley with a woman,
Whose heart is obstinate, whose hands are feeble,
Seemeth in vain and over tedious.

sp.speaker: Caesar.
sp.l: Speak at a word cannon is my next parley,
You will not yield your state to save their lives.

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.p: I will not Caesar.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.p: Cut of both their heads.

sp.speaker: 1. Boy.
sp.l: Let us entreat our mother noble general,
For to deliver up the state of Furly
And will you save our lives then.

sp.speaker: 2. Boy.
sp.p: Good captain do not kill us.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p: If she will yield the state your lives are safe.

sp.speaker: 1. Boy.
sp.l: Good mother for my father's sake that's dead,
And for mine uncle's sake part of your bowels
And for our own sakes yield yourselves and save us.

sp.speaker: 2. Boy.
sp.p: Good sweet mother save us.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.l: Poor boys, in heart unlike Riario's race,
Or Sforza's warlike lineage by the mother
Know what it is die with liberty,
And live with ignominious servitude.
If you your lives buy with the loss of states
It were of all extremities the vilest
But in extremity to die resolved
Preserving state and reputation:
is said to die within the bed of honour,
This is an honour for Riario's children,
And for my part, it never shall be said,
That Katherine being strong upon her guard,
Having good forces able to defend,
In brutish feat should give away your states,
I rather will obtrude myself unarmed,
And meet the thickest ranks that enter breach,
To be tossed up upon their soldiers pikes,
Sooner I will set all the town on fire,
And with my soldiers sacrifice myself,
Rather than render up your heritage,

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.p: O bravely spoken warlike amazon.

sp.speaker: 1. Boy.
sp.l: Mother we scorn death in respect of honour
Let him perform his worst, we fear him not,
Courage sweet brother, think upon my father,
I will die first, be not afraid of death.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.p: Why then you are resolved to die?

sp.speaker: 1. Boy.
sp.p: I to die Caesar.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.p: Bring hither both their heads.

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.l: God's blessing rest with you my dearest sons
And if I lose your states, my life shall follow,
Nothing but violence shall force it from us,
Ere long this quarrel twixt us will stand even:
Farewell dear boys, till we three meet in heaven.

sp.speaker: 2. boy
sp.p: Ah dear mother, sweet mother, good uncle Inlio save our lives.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.p: Away with him.

sp.speaker: 2. Boy.
sp.p: Let me before I die, but kiss my mother.

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.l: What wouldst thou run again into my womb?
If thou wert here thou shouldst be Posthumus,
And ripped out of my sides with soldier's swords,
Before I would yield up thine heritage.

sp.speaker: 1. Boy.
sp.p: Come brother let us bravely die together.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: I tell thee when that these have lost their heads,
I will make sack and pillage of your state,
Man, women, orphans, all put to the sword,
This hath your obstinacy wrought in us,
carry them hence, bring hither both their heads. Exeunt with the boys,
And then a charge upon this valiant lady,
This 〈◊〉, this proud Semeramis,
Whose valour Barbarossa by these heavens,
Is very wonderful and glorious.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: Had he more force, what would this tyrant do?

sp.speaker: C●●.
sp.p: A charge a charge.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: For God's sake charge, a charge let us to sight.

sp.speaker: C●s.
sp.l: A spirit full of vengeance, wrath, and spite,
Assault, assault, charge noble hearts a charge.

div.stage: A charge with a peal of ordinance: Caesar after two retreats entreth 〈◊〉 scalado, her ensign-bearer slain: Katherin recouereth the ensign, and sighteth with it in her hand. Here she showeth excellent magnanimity. Cesar the third time repulsed, at length entereth by scalado, surpriseth her, bringeth her down with some prisoners. Sound drums and trumpets.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: Courageous Kate, you that would throw defiance
Into the face and throat of fate and Caesar,
Such are the fruits of pride and wilfulness.
Have I performed my word? are you surprised?
Is not your life and living in my power?

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.l: Now that my sons first by insidious means,
Bereft of their lives, and their states lost,
The date of my calamities is out,
Go forward with thy tyranny, strike Caesar,
And take away the mother with her sons:
This done, recount what is thy victory.
A woman with two children vanquished,
A prize befitting the renown of Caesar.

sp.speaker: C●s.
sp.l: Come hither Katherine wonder of thy sex,
The grace of all Italian womanhood:
Caesar shall never prove dishonourable,
Behold thy children living in my tent.

div.stage: He discovereth his tent where her two sons were a● cards.

sp.speaker: 2. Boy.
sp.p: O mother, mother, are you come, we be not dead.

sp.speaker: 1. Boy.
sp.l: Good mother, thank the captain, we live yet,
They gave us spices, wines, and bade us welcome,
I pray you thank them.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: O but your lands and honours are both lost,
Had not an honourable death been better:
Then thus to lose your states and livelihoods.
Heroic soldier, whose deceit is honour.
Thou that hast unexpected saved the lives
Of my two children, I submit them here
Thy captives, for their ransom what is fit.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: I freely pardon these two boys their ransom,
Lady behold thy treasure in my tent,
Had I not won this town, this hadst thou lost,
See soldiers that her jewels be reserved
For her own service, now the quarrel ends.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.l: But noble Caesar well entreat our people,
They be men valiant, civil, obedient,
If you their magistrates entreat them well.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: Take you the charge of Furly, Barbarossa,
Entreat the people well, do not restrain them,
We freely pardon all of them their ransoms,
So much as is in us, we pardon all,
Use them as citizens of Rome in favour,
Other instructions you shall have hereafter:
Till then regard your charge and so farewell.
sp.stage: Enter with a drum, Barbarossa, soldiers.
sp.l: Lady, yourself, with your two little babes,
I will take order shall be sent to Rome,
Be not dismayed, you shall be well entreated,
You shall want nothing fitting your estates,
March with us on our way for Capua.

div.stage: March Caesar, Katherine, her two boys, ensigns, soldiers, trumpets, drums. Exeunt.

div.head: Scae. 5.
div.stage: Enter Alexander out of his study.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Bring in that opium, and bowl of wine,
Here I must act a tragicomedy,
Bernardo is it well confected and prepared?
According to my conference with Rotsi.

div.stage: Bernardo with a flagon of wine and a bowl

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: He sent it as your holiness may see,
Safe sealed up

sp.speaker: Alex,
sp.p: Fill me that bowl of wine,

div.stage: Alexander openeth a box and putteth in the powder.

sp.speaker: B●r.
sp.p: 'Tis a drowsy medicine, do not taste it my lord,

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Thou hast been taster to me, many times,
Begin Bernardo.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: My lord I slept too much the last night and I dare not,

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: It holds good colour hold here Bernardo,
Give good attendance, bring them to their rest,
Then give me notice at my study door.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: One set was passed before I parted from them,
And by this time they be well heated.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Sirrah be diligent and serviceable in this,
Even as thou lovest thy master. Exit Alexander into his study.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Fear me not?
Were it not that my conscience hath been fired,
With flames of purgatory by this Pope,
I never could endure such villainy,
The best is he doth pardon all my sins. Exit Bernardo.

div.stage: Enter Astor and Philippo in their waistcoats with rackets.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: This set was strangely lost I durst have wagered,
An hundred ducats after the first chase.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: You think you play well, but believe me brother,
You cannot take pains not observe a ball,
With that dexterity which appertaineth.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: Holla within there if I take no pains,
My waistcoat well can witness for I sweat. Enter Bernardo.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Barber bring in some linen for my lords

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Bring me some wine for I am very thirsty

div.stage: Enter two barbers with linen.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: I listened for that string and he hath touched it.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Will't please your lordship sit on this low chair?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Rub my head first then comb it,

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.p: Fill me some wine Bernardo,

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Good my lord cool yourself a little,

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: Give me wine and let it be thy labour good Barnardo
To call for music. Bernardo delivereth wine.
Brother in this cup I commend the loves,
Of all true faventines our trusty friends,
Hoping ere long to live again with them.

sp.speaker: Phi
sp.l: I thank you brother, if our father Pope.
Perform his promise we shall soon return.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: This wine was good yet tasteth of the cask,
It hath a musty relish.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Let's here this music,

div.stage: After the barbers had trimmed and rubbed their bodies a little, Astor caleth.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.p: Holla within there.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: My lord.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.p: I think it good after this little rubbing to repose my body

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I am some what heavy.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: I know the cause,

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.p: And what Bernardo.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Marry with much motion of your bodies my lords,
You must not be so vehement in play.
I knew a noble French man at Anchona,
Twenty years since at tennis took his death.
With over heating of himself in play.

div.stage: They lay themselves upon a bed and the barber's dep●●●.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: More music there.

div.stage: After one strain of music they fall asleep :

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: My lords are both asleep music depart.
And leave them to their ease; alas sweet boys,
Is it not pity that these noble branches,
So sweetly knit in one, should never wake?
I that am hard of heart sigh for their sake,
My lord. Bernardo knocketh at the study.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: What news man?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Both fast asleep .

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: And both upon one bed?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: 'Tis done.

sp.speaker: Alex:
sp.p: And chamber voided?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: All is performed my lord.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: My blessing rest upon thee my Benardo.
Depart now with those letters I delivered,
To be conveyed to Florence leave me here.
sp.stage: Alexander upon the stage in his cassock and 〈◊〉 ●●ap with a box under each arm. Alexander solus.
sp.l: Sleep both secure upon your fatal bed,
Now that the God of silence Morpheus,
Hath with his figure to● black horn sealed up,
Your languid eye lids loaden with pale death,
Sleep until you draw your latest breath,
Poor harmless boys strangers to sin and evil,
O were my soul as innocent as yours!
This office is of highest consequence,
In friendship for I consider it,
I sent you from a million of sorrows,
Into the flowery fields of paradise.
Their to go habit in the groves of myrtle,
To feed on manna and to drink pure nectar,
A cup of everlasting happiness.
Where such sweet music unconceivable,
Shall entertain your senses in sweet comfort,
As the delight thereof shall never die
Astor what Astor speak awake Phillippo,
Both fast asleep . He stirreth and moveth them opening both their bosoms.
Now Roderick betake thee to thy task,
What? peace Astor begins to talk I will attend.

div.stage: Astor speaketh in his sleep.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: Fair gracious angel of eternal light,
Which reachest out that hand of happiness.
Hailing my spirit to that triumphant throne,
Of endless comfort I adore thy grace.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: In his sleep.o golden light of never setting sun,
Hark brother Astor hark my soul is rapt,
Into the joys of heaven with harmony.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Do they not sleep? are they not yet asleep ?
Be not their senses yet locked up in sleep.
Astor awake awake, awake Philippo.
All safe and sure, o this was but a dream,
Their genius hath fore told them of their end,
And joyfully they do shake hands with death.
sp.stage: He draweth out of his boxes aspics.
sp.l: Come out here now you Cleopatra's birds.
Fed fat and plump with proud Egyptian slime,
Of seven mouthed Nilus but now turned lean:
sp.stage: He putteth to either of their breasts an aspike.
sp.l: Take your repast upon these princely paps.
Now Ptolemy's wife is highly magnified,
Ensigning these fair princely twins their death,
And you my lovely boys competitors,
With Cleopatra share in death and fate.
Now Charon stays his boat upon the strand,
And with a rugged for head full of wrath
He thrusts a million from the shore of Styx,
To give you waftage to the Elysian fields,
I see their colours change and death sits heavy.
On their fair foreheads with his leaden mace.
My birds are glutted with this sacrifice.
sp.stage: He taketh of the aspics and putteth them up in his box.
sp.l: What now proud worms? how tastes you princes blood.
The slaves be plump and round in to your nests,
Is there no token of the serpent's draught,
All clear and safe well now fair boys goodnight.
Bernardo, Bernardo, the feat is done,
Use thy discretion as I did direct. Exit Alexander.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: 'Tis done in deed alas they both be dead:
Now must I follow my directions,
holla within there. Enter Cardinal Caraffa with Bentivogli.

sp.speaker: Caer.
sp.p: What news Bernardo?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Alas my lord ill news,
But that his holiness is fast asleep ,
And this day stirred not from his bedchamber
I would have brought him to this woeful sight:
Prince Astor with Phillippo was at tennis,
And being overheated at their game,
Drinking so suddenly upon that heat,
With much sweet wine did surfeit instantly,
And here alas lie dead upon this bed.

sp.speaker: Bent.
sp.l: Alas it is a ruthful spectacle,
Two princely boys of noble disposition,
Endued with honourable gifts of virtue.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Of gracious favour, wise, and liberal.
Phaenza's hope: Bernardo bear them in,
His holiness will much bemoan their fate.

sp.speaker: Bent.
sp.p: My lord, my lord, I do not like of this.

sp.speaker: Caraf.
sp.p: Peace man, no more do I, but bear with patience.

sp.speaker: Bent.
sp.l: It is suspicious but we may not talk,
Come let us in, o God!

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: O God what times are these. Exeunt omnes.
After the bloody Duke Valentinoys
Had conquered Furly, with the warlike lady,
By wily force he took in Capua,
Then through insidious sleights and treacheries,
He did surprise the state of Camerine,
Where he captived Julio di Varana,
With his two sons all which he strangled,
With semblable tyranny proud Caesar,
On terms of trust meets with the Duke Gravina,
And Vitellozzo with the prince of Fermo:
Whom he betrayed at Sinigaglia,
Bereaving them both of their states and lives,
He conquereth Urbin; and with violence,
performeth strange and hideous outrages.
By this time with his forces back to Rome,
Caesar is marching; what betided there,
Ends in the subject of this tragedy.

div.head: Scae. 1.
div.stage: Enter Caesar after a flourish of trumpets with Drums, ensigns, soldiers. Barbarossa, Cardinal Caraffa Bentivogli. Baglioni.

sp.speaker: Caesa.
sp.l: Now that by cunning force and policy,
All the free states and cities of Romania
Subjected are unto the church of Rome.
And that our pikes and swords in blood and slaughter,
Are stained and sheathed quiet in our scabbards,
Our blood and wounds staunched and bound up in scarves,
Let us for this could season of the year,
Rest us and cheer ourselves till the next spring.
And then march forward with alacrity.
Brave Barbarossa take these soldiers,
Unto some quarter where by sound of drum,
According to their muster give them pay,
Let them be satisfied and so discharged.
Fellows in arms faithful and valiant,
I thank you for your pains and honesties,
In token of our good heart to your service,
We give each common soldier more than pay,
Two ducats: and all other officers.
According to their place redoubled,
With many thanks for your exceeding valour,
Assuring you that in these wars with us,
Caesar shall make you captains of your spoils,
And so doth he commend you to your ease.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.p: A Caesar a Caesar God save Caesar. Exit Barba.

div.stage: Sound trumpets and a flourish with drums marching with soldiers,

sp.speaker: Caesa.
sp.l: Sirrah come hither you must wait on me.
My good lord Cardinal and Bentivoli,
Much thanks and dear acceptance of your loves,
I lovingly return for your great pains.

sp.speaker: Cara●.
sp.l: His holiness gave us in serious charge,
To give you greeting and withal prepares
A sumptuous feast for that solemnity.
To which he doth invite the Cardinals
With other lords your favourers in Rome.

sp.speaker: C●s.
sp.l: Humbly commend my duty to my father
Tell him this night I purpose to be with him,
sp.stage: Pointing at letters in his hand.
sp.l: Tell him I live in health and touching these,
I pray you certify his holiness,
I will have special care: and so my lords
For a small season I will take my leave.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: We do congratulate your safe return.

div.stage: Exit Caraffa and Bent. Cesar looketh on his letters.

sp.speaker: Caes
sp.l: Come hither Baglioni speak sincerely,
Know'st thou Brandino Rotsi th'apothecary.

sp.speaker: Bag.
sp.p: What I my gracious lord? know I myself?

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.p: How should I know that sir?

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: May it please your highness he serves his holiness.

sp.speaker: C●.
sp.l: He did indeed sometime and for his villainies,
Is worthily cast of; but tell me sirrah:
Thou dost remember how for breach of arms
When thou didst stab a certain lancepresado:
I pardoned thee thy life.

sp.speaker: Bag
sp.l: True my good lord I very well remember,
He was a lousy villain, marry was he,
And if he lived yet such is my stomach,
That were he chopped in mammocks I could eat him:
But for that honour in a soldier's word
He spend my life to do your highness' service.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.p: Hast thou thy piece then ready.

sp.speaker: Bag.
sp.l: O my good lord lies fix, sound as a bell,
with all my warlike furniture beside
Good flask and touchbox, a Valentia blade
A slavish dagger, powder of Rheims and bullets
Here they been.

sp.speaker: C●s.
sp.l: Sometime this afternoon within the park,
Next, to the Vatican, Ratsie will be:
And as I know thee stout and resolute,
Bestow a bullet on him as he passeth;
Few words; if any man attach thee for it,
By my protection thou shalt be enlarged.

sp.speaker: Bag.
sp.l: And if I do not my good lord dam me for it
I have an old grudge at him coal black cur,
He shall have two steel bullets strongly charged
Nay but hear me my lord?
I'll tell you what,
By this true fox of steel
I had as good a spaniel for the water,
As ever hunted duck: and this true villain
Because my dog did eat up a pannado
Within his house; what did that Spanish rogue?
What did he think you my lord?
Marry very fair and instantly
Poisoned my spaniel with rosa-solis,
A pox on him mitcher, faith I'll pay him his old fivepence for't now.

sp.speaker: C●s.
sp.l: Take this to buy thee clothes my trusty servant,
Nay 'tis gold be not afeard of it.

sp.speaker: Bag.
sp.l: Afeard my lord
Were it a tempest in a shower of gold
I would endure it and adore you for't.

sp.speaker: C●s.
sp.l: Then Baglion fit thee, to thy furniture,
Watch in a corner close beyond some tree:
And when the deed is done repair to me:
Say that thy piece went off against thy will,
Keep a light match in cock, wear flask and touchbox:
And take a murrain with thee so farewell;
thus must I dive deep in a villain's nature,
And thus must save a villain from the gallows
To play my parts in others purposes.
The man whom I to benefit would choose,
I must in matters of more moment use:
Or else I will not benefit a man,
And cut him of in sequel if I can.

sp.speaker: B●g.
sp.l: Hear me, but my good lord mark my words well,
If old Henrilico shrink in this service
Cashier him, call him whipstock, let him perish,
For want of spanish wines, and malvasy.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.p: Then fail not my true servant finely, closely. Exit caes.

sp.speaker: Bag.
sp.l: No more, but by this cross,
Why now this noble Caesars like himself,
Hath fitted me with service: if the world,
Had sought out somewhat to content a man,
Nothing could better please old Ballion
Then to kill a rascal, coward, cur,
A Spanish squirt-up, a black poisoning toad.
I like this trading better than the wars
For there I serve for two ducats a month,
And not a duck egg richer when I march
And in continual hazard of my life
For which percase my piece kills twenty persons:
Now shall I march in purse with many ducats,
For one hours service but to kill one man,
Free from all danger of mine enemy,
I will about it and take up my stand. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Bernardo.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: Thus doth one hideous act succeed another,
Until the mouth of mischief be made up:
Now must I train my fellow to his death,
A deed of such and I did swear the same,
Not only for the secrecy thereof.
But to conceal a matter of more weight,
Of greater moment and high cruelty:
When any deed of murder must be done,
To serve his holiness, call for Bernardo.
He must be principal or accessary
To serve all purposes; for gold or pardon,
The Pope gives both; and I can take them both:
Gold can make hard the softest conscience,
And mine is hardened by the practice of it.
Holla signior Bandino. He knocketh at a door,

div.stage: Enter Rotsie.

sp.speaker: Rot.
sp.l: Who calls without there? what my good fellow Bernardo?
Very welcome: what news with you?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: My lord hath sent me for the things he spoke of.

sp.speaker: Rot.
sp.l: Here they be very strong and sufficiently compounded
According to directions from his holiness,
And special warrant under his privy signet
I tried them on three men condemned to death:
For rapine and vile murder: but the first
Within less than one quarter of an hour,
Puffed up, grew leprous and his heart strings broke;
Then did I give allay the second time,
The second prisoner died within three hours
I did the third time mitigate, a little,
And saw when it was ministered the third man,
Who did within eight hours swell, rage and die.

sp.speaker: Ber,
sp.l: Well have you done your part, set down your bottles,
And read this letter from the Duke Valentinoys,

div.stage: He setteth down his bottles and walking readeth to himself.

sp.speaker: Bag.
sp.l: Well said brave pincoginger, by mine honour
Before I do this service lie there piece.
For I must have a saying to those bottles,He drinketh.
sp.p: True stingo stingo by mine honour. O that mine old friend and boccadillio Frescobaldi wear hear alive again to taste of this other bottle, well I will venture upon it, that I may drink one health to Frescobaldi I will encounter with this stout Hectorean, Greek.
sp.l: Were Meleager here that slew the boor.
Like a Boracchio armed all in sack,
Or stout Achilles in a pewter coat.
Or old Assaracus armed in a wicker jerkin,
Or Priamus armed with a leather jacket,
Lined and embossed with Alligant and hollock
By force of arms and Mars his valiant hand,
I would encounter them whilst I could stand.
The slaves are busy reading their Paphlagonian papers,
I must have a saying to you sir I must; though,
You be provided for his holiness own mouth; I will be,
Bold to be the Pope's taster by his leave.
Now trusty Troilus, base los manos.

sp.speaker: Rot
sp.l: Let him alone it is the Duke's pleasure,
That if he will taste he shall be suffered,
And therefore I was commanded to set them down,
In presence of such a fellow whom for his sauciness,
I have peppered.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: O 'tis a perilous villain if you knew him so well as I, believe me he would pepper you for it if he understood so much, peace man he hath broken up the bottle let him drink.

sp.speaker: Rotsi.
sp.p: Nay let him drink and burst, for believe me I was informed before of such a fellow; for whom I was commanded to lay bate; o notable villain, how he sealeth death.

sp.speaker: Brg.
sp.l: This is a noble nipster i'faith, so so. He drinketh.
Back again to kennel slave.

sp.speaker: Rot.
sp.p: He hath his full wages doubt not Bernardo, to serve him till he die, seem not to respect him in any case do I pray you.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Nay but do not you respect him, lest he doubt you suspect him.

sp.speaker: Rot.
sp.p:
O doubt you not, doubt you not, I will never look, let us
turn our talk. Tell his holiness 'tis well compounded and composed of all those drugs mentioned in your letter, give the Duke right humble thanks for his token, and with all reverence kiss his excellent hand.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: And by this signet you are to deliver me the bottles.

sp.speaker: Rot.
sp.p: Have a care of them and deliver them.

div.stage: Bernardo receiveth the bottles.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Farewell fellow Rotsi.

sp.speaker: Rot.
sp.p: Adieu Bernardo.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Now do not I pity this Spanish villain because he consented to the poisoning of this soldier, but for that I am innocent.

div.stage: They go forth two several ways and Rotsi is shot by Baglioni.

sp.speaker: Bag.
sp.p:
What is the wild goose fallen? have at you sir, might a poor soldier speak half a score words to your venomous worship and according to your accustomed surliness have no replyal: I believe you sir, your words are not offensive in any sort I must confess. Now thou infectious slave, thou compictious rascal, thou confectionary villain: where is you sublimatum now sir? where is your ratsbanatum now? now where are your poisoned pullets in stewed-broth? where be they? you never dreamt of a poisoned ballet, did you go too? now signior currigantino will I rummage in the worm eaten keel of your rotten hulk: passion of my soul what papers are these. Foh powder, powder foh, what's here I marry sir I like this well, are you so pursy sir, this may serve to stop a gap in my neighbour's hedge, what is this you show me with a shame to you, yea and master of the small ordinance to, this basilisk hath been often mounted where there hath been hot and dangerous service in the I'll of Japan, hold passion of me my guts, out upon thee thou hast poisoned me with thy stinking breath or with thy villonous powders out alas alas what fiery commotions I feel in my body groping fretting and fuming, a plague on your
bottle ale with a vengeance, I am peppered there is no remedy in all these extreme agonies! must draw this villain further: and throw him into a ditch, deh veleno dell diabolo, farewell farewell my old shurcordillio Frescobaldi ▪ farewell madam Sempronia, for in conscience I am guilty of mine own death o the pangs of hell and purgatory; come you lousy rascal I will bury thee with carrion in the next ditch.

div.stage: He draweth in Rotsi by the heels groaning.

div.head: Scae. 3.
div.stage: Alexander, Caesar Borgia.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Have you delivered to the bottleman,
The fatal wine.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: I I gave charge to Bernardo,
Having them safely sealed with mine own signet,
That when feasting I do call for wine,
He shall break up the seals and fill that out,
For the two Cardinals Cornetto and Modina.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: 'Tis well, now if our plot prove right,
Thou shalt be master of much wealth tonight ,
Dying in estate all comes to my share,
Caraffa loves a salad passing well,
And I have fitted one to serve his turn,
Their gold will make thy soldiers fight in blood,
And wing thy victories with good success.

sp.speaker: Caesa.
sp.l: Let us no longer entertain the time,
By this the Cardinals expect our presence.

sp.speaker: Allex.
sp.l: On with auspicious steps triumphant Caesar.
And entertain them in brave jollity.

div.stage: Exit.

div.head: Scae. 4.
div.stage: Sound loud music: a cuppord of plate brought in. Enter with bottles Bernardo with the bottleman.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Have special care you that have these in charge.
That these two sealed bottles be not stirred,
Until his holiness call for that wine

sp.speaker: Bot.
sp.p: Fear not I will attend it as my life.

div.stage: Sound trumpets solemnly, enter a table spread, viands brought in: after the trumpets sound drums and sif; enter Alexander in his pontificals, after him Cornetto with Caesar, Barbarossa with Modina, Bentiuoli with Caraffa, the Pope taketh his place, three Cardinals on one side and captains on th●ther.

sp.speaker: Alx.
sp.l: Martial yourselves here sworne-men and their
Churchmen.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p: Here sit we swordmen to defend the church.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: My lords give answer in sincerity,
Hath not my Caesar fought well for the church?
That hath so soon subjected in her right.
Imola, Furly, Camerino, Capua,
Urbine, Faenza ▪ Sinegaglia.
Brave Caesar I must boast of it in presence,
That I Christ's vicar of his church on earth,
Have such a son which issued from my loins,
That being vicar of the church's wars.
Hath in revolution of one year,
Done more than all the generals have done,
In honour of our church for forty years,

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: Your holiness with all your Cardinals,
Your barons and indeed all Christendom
Are bound to give God thanks for such a prince.
And him great honour for his fortitude.

div.stage: The devil cometh and changeth the Pope's bottles.

sp.speaker: M●d.
sp.l: Your excellence did in a blessed hour.
Surrender up your holy robes and hat,
Be taking 〈…〉 and arms,
By which you might enlarge our liberties.

sp.speaker: Ca●.
sp.p: 〈◊〉 my lord and see we have all of us good cause to rejoice, would I had been with your excellence at Capua, I would h●d one boat with them as old as I am.

sp.speaker: C●s
sp.l: You might my lord have had your choice of ladies,
Beautiful prisoners to be sent to Rome.

sp.speaker: Cara ▪
sp.p: I marry my lord some what might have been said to this gear to die●● 〈◊〉, but transeant cum ceteris erroribus, would to God I wear as young as when I was a scholar in Padua, faith then I could have swinged a sword and a buckler, and I did that then will being but a spring all of 24. years which be talked of in Padua these 40. years I warrant it faith my lord were I so lusty now I would go with you to the waires this next spring that's flat, will you eat any salad my lord, faith here are excellent herbs if you love them.

sp.speaker: C●sa.
sp.p: They be my lord too cold for my stomach, wilt please you my lord to drink a cup of old Greek wine with it, bring me some wine here.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Bring me some wine here I will drink a joy to Caesar and this noble company.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.p: Some wine for his holiness own mouth, Bernardo.

div.stage: Wine is brought to Alexander.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Cesar yourself are master of this feast,
I drink a good success and victory,
To Caesar and great happiness to all.

div.stage: Caesar drinketh.

sp.speaker: Caesa.
sp.p: Happy success and fortune to you all.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Hold Caesar; stay for we are poisoned,

div.stage: Rush from the table.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.p: My lord it is all of.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Then art thou quite undone.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Some villainous conspiracy lies hid
Within this company, and this pernicious villain
Hath practised with them; go with thy soul to hell,
I feel the raging of it.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: Away my lord Modina come away,
This train was laid of purpose for our lives.

sp.speaker: Modi,
sp.l: Our refuge and defence is from above,
Let Sathan work, he never shall prevail.

div.stage: Exit corn and Modina.

sp.speaker: Caraff
sp.p: How doth my gracious lord.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: O very sick ● bring me preservatives,
I think I have as good as any man. Alex. to his study.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: My lord Bentivogli take here my keys,
You know my study, search my cabinet,
There shall you find a little crystal vial,
Wrapped up in sarsenet bring it hither straight,
I feel vesonus raging in my guts. Exit.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Here Cesar taste some of this precious water,
Against all plague, poison, and pestilence
A present help: I bought it of a Jew,
Born and brought up in Galily. Caesar tasteth.

sp.speaker: C●s.
sp.p: My lord it is too forceable and hot.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: The flames of Mongibell consume my liver,
Bring me to some repose.

sp.speaker: Caraff.
sp.p: Comfort yourself my lord.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Cesar take rest,
Send for physicians, all my fear remains
That Caesar shall miscarry.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: And all my grief that both.
Noble Bentivogli withdraw we both,
Unto my chamber, I am very sick. Exeunt omnes.

div.head: Scen. 5.
div.stage: Enter Astaroth and calleth.

sp.speaker: Asta.
sp.p: Belchar, Belchar, Belchar;

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Varca, Varca, Varca,

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.p: Astaroth, Astaroth, Astaroth.

div.stage: The devils meet and embrace.

sp.speaker: Asto.
sp.l: Let Orcus Erebus and Acheron,
And all those ghosts which haunt the pitchy vaults
Of coal black hags in Cimmerian shades
Muster themselves in numbers numberless,
To dance about the ghost of Alexander.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: Our fiery region void of all religion,
And devilish order by necessity,
Compelled requires his present policy.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: That fatal wine which for his Cardinals,
He destined I took out of the place:
And placed his own wine for those Cardinals.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: The date of his damnation is at hand.

sp.speaker: Asta.
sp.l: Be ready then for I the first will bear,
As swift as whirlwind his black soul to Styx.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: And I with poisoned toads will stop his mouth,
Whose heart was never satisfied with lust.

sp.speaker: Asta.
sp.l: And I with snakes and stinging scorpions
Will scourge him for his pride and insolence.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: And I with force of fiends will hall his limbs,
And pull them till he stretch an anchor length.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: And for his avarice I will fill his paunch,
With store of molten gold and boiling lead.

sp.speaker: Asto.
sp.p: Then let us for his sake a hornpipe tread.

div.stage: They dance an antic.

div.head: Scen. ultima.
div.stage: Alexander unbraced betwixt two Cardinals in his study looking upon a book, whilst a groom draweth the curtain.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: You talk of penance and of penitence,
Compunction with contrition and remission
For all my sins; I pray you think of yours
You vex yourselves too much I cannot thank you,
Have patience sirs; o 'tis a goodly exorcism
Quem penitet peccasse paene est innocens
Give leave, give leave, come hither when I call
Either mere fools or good physicians all.
sp.stage: They place him in a chair upon the stage, a groom setteth a table before him.
sp.l: Nay leave me good my lords, fain would I meditate,
Leave me I pray you.

sp.speaker: Caraf.
sp.l: We leave our prayers with your holiness,
Call upon God, think of his endless bounty.

sp.speaker: Ale.
sp.l: Pray for yourselves, trouble not me with prayers,
I pray you trouble not yourselves with praying.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Solus. What is repentance? have I not forgotten?
Why repentance is a spiritual martyrdom,
Which mortifieth sins and heals the soul:
Having been wounded with the spirit's sword
This sword God's book: that book by me profaned
And by which book of God my soul is damned,
I damned undoubtedly.
O wretched Alexander, slave of sin
And of damnation; what is he that can
Deliver thy poor soul? o none but he
That when thou didst renounce him cast of thee,
Repentance is in vain, mercy too late,
o why should miserable mortal man,
Whose languashing breath lives in his nostrils
Vex and torment himself with daily travel
To scrape up heaps of gold to gape for honours?
What were the conquests of great Alexander:
Of Cyrus, Cayus Caesar? what were it
To be possessed of this universe
And leave it all behind him in a moment?
Might some one man attain that happiness
Which our first Adam had in paradise,
Before he did prevaricate? why then
It were a work of lasting worthiness
To rip the bowels of our mother Ops
For treasure; and to conquer all the world,
Because eternity would promise it,
Out, out alas my pains, my guts, my liver
And yet I fear it not though in security
Once more I will with powerful exorcisms,
Invoke those angels of eternal darkness
To show me now the manner of death.

div.stage: Alexander draweth the curtain of his study where he discovereth the devil sitting in his pontificals, Alexander crosseth himself starting at the sight.

sp.speaker: Devil
sp.l: What dost thou start foul child of reprobation
Vain are thy crosses, vain all exorcisms,
Those be no fruits of faith but mere hypocrisy:
Signa te signa temeré me tangis et angis
Roma tibi subito motibus ibit amor.
Rome which once was thy gorgeous concubine
Hath now forsaken thee: now doth she find,
Thy falsehood which did her adulterate
What dost thou tremble slave of sin and hell?

div.stage: Alexander taketh his book of magicke, the devil laugheth.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: I exorcise thee foul malignant spirit
In the names of, of, of —

sp.speaker: Devil.
sp.l: Of what? foul mouth, polluted soul?
Corrupted flesh; God hath forsaken thee,
Thy date expired it, thy power determined.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Dissolve dissolve, break, break, black soul dissolve,
And poison all this hem so here with sin.

sp.speaker: Devil
sp.l: Thy death and dissolution stand at door,
Resolve now to dissolve, thy soul is ours.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Proud Lucifer traitor, to great Jehovah,
Father of lies my time is not expired
I will not do that violence to God,
Taking that which is his from him
To be bestowed on his great enemy.

sp.speaker: Devil
sp.l: Thou that hast thrown those graces in his face,
How canst thou think upon salvation?
Think that thou'rt damned. I will declare it plainly.

div.stage: They sit together.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Seven years are yet to come, I look for them.

sp.speaker: Devil
sp.p: Examine thy soul with this counterpart.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Behold it? is it not for eight years and 8 days?

sp.l: the best you can,
Where other creatures carried with blind force,
Make themselves bondslaves to the present time.
The scope of man's creation was to glorify
The most all potent maker of all things,
The Alpha and Omega of all bounty.
But he that wilfully betrays this soul,
That precious jewel wherein God delights,
Dishonours God and doth deprive himself,
Of all salvation and beatitude.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Rest with this answer, that my soul is gods
Whose habitacle is prepared in heaven.
First it doth know God being figured
According to that image of himself,
And then the world whose lively shape it bears,
And to conclude the soul of man knows all,
Because with all things it doth symbolize,
For in this man there is a mind intelligent,
A quickening word and a celestial spirit,
That like a lightning every way diffused,
All things which are made by the mighty power,
Uniteth, moveth, and replenisheth.

sp.speaker: Devil
sp.l: These things should have been thought upon before,
The summum bonum which lives in the soul,
Is an eternal pleasure to behold,
And have fruition of the mighty power.
Which thou didst never see, nor canst enjoy.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p:
Pause yet a little, let me meditate,Alexander holdeth up his hands wring and softly crying.
Mercy, mercy, mercy; arise arise: up, up, up: fie, fie: no, no? stir stubborn, stony, stiff indurate heart not yet, up. why, what? wilt thou not foul traitor? to my soul? not yet?
sp.l: Arise, arise, advance heart clogged with sin,
Oppressed with damnation: up advance yet.
Wilt thou not stir stiff heart? what am I damned?
Yet a little, yet a little, o yet: not yet? alas.
High God of heavens and earth if thou bear love,
Unto the soul of sinful man show mercy,
Mercy good lord, o mercy, mercy, mercy.
O save my soul out of the lion's paws,
My darling from the den of black damnation,
My soul, my dove, cover with silver wings,
Her down and plumage make of fine tried gold,
Help, help, help, above ▪ stir, stir, stupidity.

sp.speaker: Devil
sp.p: He charms in David's words with Judas spirit,

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: It will not, no it will not, yet alas, no, no, no? is that my sentence to damnation?
I am undone, undone.

sp.speaker: Devil.
sp.l: He shall despair, vassal of sin and hell,
Provide thyself in black despair to dwell.

div.stage: He seizeth on his face.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: I tell thee I cannot be resolved,
To dwell in darkness break black soul dissolve,
And poison all this hemisphere with sin,

div.stage: Here Alexander is in extreme torment and groneth whilst the devil laugheth at him.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: And if I may not reach that happiness,
Since for my son's sake I myself enthralled,
Tell me shall Caesar die this death with me?

sp.speaker: Devil.
sp.l: Caesar; his youth and strength of blood drives out
This fat all poison and shall live a while.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: O show me then the manner of his death,

sp.speaker: Devil
sp.p: Attend it time grows short all fear is past.

div.stage: the devil bringeth from the door Lucrecia's ghost, and after her the ghost of Candy stabbed.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: What means that ghastly shadow which came first?

sp.speaker: Devil.
sp.l: By that which represents Lucretia,
Leprous and poisoned is thy death declared,
By poison which now struggleth with thy spirits,
And by that other which sets out to thee,
The murder of thy son the Duke of Candy,
Prefigured is the death of thy son Caesar,
Thou for the poisoning of thy daughter poisoned:
He for the murthering of his brother murdered.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Thus God is only just.

sp.speaker: Devil
sp.p: The devil cannot deny it.

sp.speaker: Alex
sp.l: Man only false.
Learn miserable wretched mortal men,
By this example of a sinful soul,
What are the fruits of pride and avarice,
Of cruel empire and impiety,
Of profanation and apostasy,
Of brutish lust falsehood, and perfidy,
Of deep dissembling and hypocrisy,
Learn wicked worldlings, learn, learn, learn by me
To save your souls, though I condemned be.

div.stage: Sound a horn within, enter a devil like a post.

sp.speaker: 1 devil
sp.p: Here comes a fatal message, I must hence. Exit.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: My robes, my robes; he robs me of my robes,
Bring me my robes, or take away my life,
My robes, my life, my soul and all is gone.

div.stage: Alexander falleth in an ecstasy upon the ground.

sp.speaker: 2. devil.
sp.l: From the pale horror of eternal fire,
Am I sent with the wagon of black Dis,
To guide thy spirit to the gates of death,
Therefore I summon thee to come with speed,
For orisons now stand thee not instead.

div.stage: Alexander advanceth a little.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Horror and horror, fear ensueth fear,
torment with torments is encompassed:
Despair upon despair, damnation
Upon damnation, hell and conscience,
Murder lust avarice impiety,
Vain prophanation and apostasy,
Rage and distraction tyrannise: away,
Away proud Lucifer, away.

sp.speaker: Devil.
sp.p: Away, away. the devil windeth his horn in his ear and there more devils enter with a noise encompassing him, Alexander starteth.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Holla, holla, holla, come, come, come, what, when, where when, why, deaf, strike, dead, alive, o alas, o alas, always burning, always freezing, always living, tormented, never ending, never, never, never mending, out, out, out, out, why, why, whether whether, thither.

sp.speaker: Devils.
sp.p: Thither, thither, thither.

div.stage: Thunder and lightning with fearful noise the devils thrust him down and go triumphing.
enter Cardinals and Bentivoli.

sp.speaker: Bent.
sp.p: What is he dead?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Dead, and in such a fashion,
As much affrights my spirits to remember,
Thunder and fearful lightning at his death,
Out cries of horror and extremity.

sp.speaker: Bent.
sp.l: Cause all your bells to ring my lords of Rome,
Rome is redeemed from a wicked Pope.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: God hath beheld us with his eyes of mercy,
His name be glorified, join all in prayer,
And give him praise that took away your shame.
Go your procession, sing your litanies,
And let your churches through with multitudes,
Banquets and bonfires through the city make.
In sign our church is freed from infamy,

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Even as his spirit was inflate with pride,
behold his body puffed up with poison,
His corpse shall be conveyed to saint Peeters,
Open for all beholders, that they may
See the reward of sin, amend and pray.
Th'omnipotent great guider of all powers,
(Whose essence is pure grace, and heavenly love,
As he with glory crowns heroic actions,
Bearing a taste of his eternal virtue)
So semblably doth he with terror strike,
In heavy vengeance sins detestable:
As in this tragic mirror to your eyes,
Our scene did represent in Alexander,
flagitious Caesar his ambitious son,
Reserved for more calamities to come,
After he was imprisoned by the church,
Escaped into the kingdom of Navarre,
Unto King John then brother to his wife:
Where in an ambush at Viano slain,
Just Nemesis repayed his treachery.

div.head: Epilogus.
div.l: Heroic and benevolent spectators,
Your gracious ears, and curious observations,
Judicious censures, and sweet clemency,
Have thus addressed our tragic theater,
T'exchange contentment, for benignity:
Humbly devoted to your good desires.
For some delight, cause of discourse for others,
For all example, and for none offence,
Your favours are a royal recompense.
Which when our lofty muses shall perceive,
Then in more pompous and triumphant state,
Your eyes with glory shall the deed receive
Of mighty monarchs, Kings, and change of fate.
By me those persons which our scene presented,
Kiss all your hands, and wish you well contented.
